verses.text: A message concerning Egypt: See, the LORD rides on a swift cloud, and comes to Egypt. The idols of Egypt tremble before Him, and the hearts of the Egyptians melt within them.
verses.comment: This oracle opens with the LORD arriving in judgment, conquering false gods. God's coming on the clouds echoes imagery used later for Christ's return (Matt. 24:30; Mark 14:62).

verses.text: I will provoke Egyptians against Egyptians; each will fight against his brother, each against his neighbor, city against city, kingdom against kingdom.
verses.comment: Internal conflict is often God’s judgment; Christ foretold similar division as a sign of the last days (Matt. 24:7).

verses.text: The spirit of the Egyptians will be emptied within them. I will confuse their plans. They will consult idols and spirits of the dead, mediums, and familiar spirits.
verses.comment: Resorting to the occult demonstrates Egypt’s spiritual despair and confusion, in contrast to God’s truth revealed through the prophets.

verses.text: I will deliver Egypt into the hands of a harsh master. A fierce king will rule over them, declares the Lord, the LORD of Hosts.
verses.comment: Egypt, once a great power, will suffer under foreign rulers. God’s sovereignty over nations is emphasized.

verses.text: The waters of the sea will dry up, and the river will be parched and dry.
verses.comment: Water is Egypt's life; drying the Nile is a severe judgment. This echoes earlier plagues against Egypt (Ex. 7:17-21).

verses.text: The rivers will stink; the streams of Egypt will dwindle and dry up; reeds and rushes will wither.
verses.comment: Egypt’s agriculture and economy depended on the Nile and its vegetation—a collapse would be disastrous.

verses.text: The meadows by the Nile, along the banks of the Nile, and everything sown by the Nile, will wither, be blown away, and vanish.
verses.comment: The Nile was Egypt’s ‘breadbasket;’ famine recalls Joseph’s time, and God’s ability to save or judge through natural means.

verses.text: The fishermen will mourn; all who cast hooks into the Nile will lament, and those who spread nets on the water will grow weak.
verses.comment: Fishermen symbolized everyday Egyptians; this judgment affects rich and poor alike. Compare with restoration imagery in Ezekiel.

verses.text: Those who work with flax, the weavers of white cloth, will be ashamed.
verses.comment: Flax and linen were luxury exports. Compare linen’s later symbolic use for purity and the righteous in Revelation.

verses.text: The pillars of the land will be crushed; all who work for wages will be grieved in spirit.
verses.comment: Social and economic order collapses. The ‘pillars’ could symbolize both physical structures and societal leaders.

verses.text: The princes of Zoan are utterly foolish; the best counselors of Pharaoh give stupid advice. How can you say to Pharaoh, 'I am a son of the wise, a son of ancient kings?'
verses.comment: Earthly wisdom falters before God’s plans. True wisdom and authority rest with God’s appointed leaders.

verses.text: Where are your wise men now? Let them tell you, and reveal what the LORD of Hosts has planned against Egypt.
verses.comment: Echoes later calls in Daniel and Paul that only revelation from God provides true wisdom.

verses.text: The princes of Zoan have become fools, the princes of Memphis are deceived; the chiefs of her tribes have led Egypt astray.
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on failed leadership underscores the need for divinely-established guidance for God’s people.

verses.text: The LORD has mixed into her a spirit of confusion; they make Egypt stagger in all its deeds, like a drunkard in his vomit.
verses.comment: God gives Egypt over to confusion, reminiscent of the Tower of Babel (Gen. 11), signifying the consequences of pride and false worship.

verses.text: There will be nothing for Egypt that head or tail, palm branch or reed, can do.
verses.comment: Both leaders (‘head’) and commoners (‘tail’) are powerless. Only unity under God brings true restoration.

verses.text: On that day the Egyptians will be like women, and tremble with fear before the hand that the LORD of Hosts raises against them.
verses.comment: ‘Like women’ reflects ancient idiom for fear, not value. God’s mighty hand is a repeated image for His saving or judging action.

verses.text: The land of Judah will become a terror to Egypt; everyone to whom Judah is mentioned will be afraid, because of what the LORD of Hosts is planning against them.
verses.comment: God fulfills His promise to make Israel a blessing—or a source of awe—to the nations (Gen. 12:3).

verses.text: On that day five cities in the land of Egypt will speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to the LORD of Hosts; one will be called the City of the Sun.
verses.comment: Gentiles worshiping the LORD foreshadows widespread conversion and unity of faith (see also Zech. 8:23, Isa. 2:2-4). Spiritual fulfillment is found as all nations join together in God’s worship.

verses.text: On that day there will be an altar to the LORD in the midst of the land of Egypt, and a pillar to the LORD at its border.
verses.comment: Sacred worship outside Israel anticipates universal worship. The altar points to a central, unified form of sacrifice pleasing to God.

verses.text: It will be a sign and a witness to the LORD of Hosts in the land of Egypt. When they cry to the LORD because of oppressors, He will send them a Savior and a defender, and He will deliver them.
verses.comment: Savior and defender echoes the role of God’s anointed throughout Scripture, fulfilled ultimately in Christ.

verses.text: The LORD will make Himself known to the Egyptians, and the Egyptians will know the LORD in that day. They will worship with sacrifices and offerings, make vows to the LORD, and fulfill them.
verses.comment: Unification of worship and knowledge of the LORD across nations fulfills prophetic hopes of global communion in God’s presence.

verses.text: The LORD will strike Egypt, striking and healing. Then they will turn to the LORD, and He will be moved by their prayers and heal them.
verses.comment: God’s judgment is medicinal, leading ultimately to repentance and healing—a pattern repeated in redemptive history and Christian life.

verses.text: On that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria. The Assyrians will go to Egypt, and Egyptians to Assyria, and Egyptians will worship with Assyrians.
verses.comment: This symbolizes reconciliation of ancient enemies through shared worship. The 'highway' reflects unity and accessibility, like the Church’s catholicity (universality) drawing all nations together.

verses.text: On that day Israel will be the third, together with Egypt and Assyria; a blessing in the midst of the land.
verses.comment: Israel, Egypt, and Assyria—formerly hostile—become ‘a blessing.’ God’s plan is unity of peoples under His covenant.

verses.text: Whom the LORD of Hosts has blessed, saying, 'Blessed be Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My inheritance.'
verses.comment: God extends His covenant language to Gentiles, calling them ‘My people.’ God’s inheritance is expanded, embracing all nations. This anticipates the fullness of the universal Church, which transcends divisions and unites humanity.
